lines.content: A chatbot meticulously crafted through countless sleepless nights, fueled by an unyielding passion for CS2113 and an endless supply of coffee, all while stationed before a 14-inch screen.
Simply download the ip.jar file. Then run by right-clicking and selecting "open in terminal".
It should start the application right away.
Good thing that you also asked.
This chatbot contains **some** basic functions to document and keep track of tasks.
To do so, simply type in the following:
- **To store "event" type events:** event [event description] /from [yyyy-MM-dd HHmm] /to [yyyy-MM-dd HHmm]
- **To store "deadline" type events:** deadline [event description] /by [yyyy-MM-dd HHmm]
- **To mark an event by its index in the list:** mark [index]
- **To unmark an event by its index in the list:** unmark [index]
- **To delete an event by its index in the list:** delete [index]
The list may or may not expand in the future. It depends on if I have enough time to finish the EE2026 project or not. Which I heard will take a lot, a lot, a lot of time.
Good thing that you also also asked.
Guess what? Every event you input will be stored via magic in a text file known as "duke.txt". It is right beside the ip.jar file.
If this is the first time you run ip.jar or, you accidentally deleted the duke.txt file, it is ok. When the jar file is run it will automatically create one in the default directory.
A chatbot meticulously crafted through countless sleepless nights, fueled by an unyielding passion for CS2113 and an endless supply of coffee, all while stationed before a 14-inch screen.
Simply download the ip.jar file. Then run by right-clicking and selecting "open in terminal".
It should start the application right away.
Good thing that you also asked.
This chatbot contains **some** basic functions to document and keep track of tasks.
To do so, simply type in the following:
- **To store "event" type events:** event [event description] /from [yyyy-MM-dd HHmm] /to [yyyy-MM-dd HHmm]
- **To store "deadline" type events:** deadline [event description] /by [yyyy-MM-dd HHmm]
- **To mark an event by its index in the list:** mark [index]
- **To unmark an event by its index in the list:** unmark [index]
- **To delete an event by its index in the list:** delete [index]
The list may or may not expand in the future. It depends on if I have enough time to finish the EE2026 project or not. Which I heard will take a lot, a lot, a lot of time.
Good thing that you also also asked.
Guess what? Every event you input will be stored via magic in a text file known as "duke.txt". It is right beside the ip.jar file.
If this is the first time you run ip.jar or, you accidentally deleted the duke.txt file, it is ok. When the jar file is run it will automatically create one in the default directory.

* Represents a "to-do" type task within the application.
* A todo task is a basic task type with a description but

* This class extends the Task class, inheriting its basic
* structure while adding specific behavior for to-do tasks, such as
* custom string representations for display and storage.

* @param description The full command input for creating the to-do,

* Task to provide details specific to to-do tasks.
* @return A string representation of the to-do task, including its
* status, which is done or not done, as well as its description.
* Provides a string formatted for storage purposes. This includes its
* It is formatted in a way that is suitable for file storage and later
* @return A string representation of the to-do task designed for storage,
* containing the task's type, completion status, and description.
* The DukeException class provides a mechanism for handling exceptions
* This class captures a variety of common errors that may occur during the execution
* of the application and provides user-friendly error messages to aid in diagnosing
* Processes and displays an appropriate message for the encountered exception.
* This method identifies the type of exception and the context in which it was thrown,
* displaying a specific message that guides the user towards resolving the problem.
* It supports handling exceptions related to null pointer access, string index out of
* bounds, array index out of bounds, I/O errors, and date-time parsing errors.
* @param error The exception that was caught during the application's execution.
* @param line The command or input that triggered the exception, used to provide
